questions.text:
A 36-year-old lady presents with myalgia and lethargy. Her blood tests show a positive ANA with a titre of 1:1024, and rheumatoid factor is negative. The CK is raised at 360 U/l. Extranuclear antigen tests show a negative Ro and negative La, negative Scl70, and positive ribonuclear protein antibody at 160 units.
What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Key findings in the question:
    • High ANA titre (1:1024)
    • Positive anti-U1 RNP (ribonuclear protein antibody)
    • Negative anti-Ro/La and anti-Scl-70
    • Myalgia with elevated CK
  • Anti-U1 RNP antibody is highly characteristic and almost diagnostic of MCTD (seen in very high titres).
  • MCTD is an overlap syndrome with features of:
    • Systemic lupus erythematosus (ANA positive)
    • Polymyositis (muscle involvement, ↑CK)
    • Systemic sclerosis (Raynaud's, sclerodactyly)
    • Sometimes rheumatoid arthritis-like features
  • Clinical hallmark: Puffy fingers and Raynaud's phenomenon are early features.
  • Response to corticosteroids is generally excellent.

Explanation of other options:

Polymyalgia rheumatica (Option A): Occurs in older patients (>50 years). Characterized by shoulder and hip girdle pain with normal CK.

Scleroderma (Systemic sclerosis) (Option B): Associated with anti-Scl70 or anti-centromere antibodies, not anti-U1 RNP.

Systemic lupus erythematosus (Option C): Positive ANA and sometimes elevated CK (rarely), but the presence of high-titre U1 RNP antibodies strongly favors MCTD over isolated SLE.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old Armenian man presents with pain and swelling of the left knee. He also gives a history of recurrent episodes of fever, pleuritic pains in the chest, and generalised rash. These episodes typically last for 2-3 days. Examination reveals splenomegaly, swollen knees, and ankles. Urine dipstick reveals 2+ proteinuria.
What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This clinical picture is classical for Familial Mediterranean Fever (FMF):

Key diagnostic clues:

  • Ethnicity: Armenian descent (high-risk population)
  • Recurrent episodes lasting 24-72 hours with complete resolution in between
  • Clinical features:
    • Fever
    • Serositis: pleuritic chest pain
    • Monoarticular arthritis (knee/ankle, non-erosive, without redness)
    • Erysipelas-like rash
    • Splenomegaly
    • Proteinuria → risk of AA amyloidosis

Autoinflammatory Syndromes:

FMF belongs to a group of disorders called autoinflammatory periodic fever syndromes, which are characterized by:

  • Recurrent fever
  • Serosal, synovial, and cutaneous inflammation
  • Absence of autoantibodies or antigen-specific T cells (unlike autoimmune diseases)
  • Risk of AA amyloidosis

Important diseases in this group:

  1. Familial Mediterranean Fever (FMF)
  2. TNF receptor-associated periodic syndrome (TRAPS)
  3. Hyperimmunoglobulinemia D with periodic fever syndrome (HIDS)
  4. NLRP3-associated autoinflammatory diseases (CAPS)

Familial Mediterranean Fever:

  • Epidemiology: Seen in Armenians, Turks, Arabs, and non-Ashkenazi Jews
  • Inheritance: Usually autosomal recessive (rarely AD)
  • Genetics:
    • Mutation in MEFV gene (pyrin) → overactivation of inflammasome → IL-1β excess
  • Clinical presentation:
    • Short febrile attacks: 1-3 days
    • Serositis: peritonitis, pleuritis, sometimes pericarditis
    • Monoarticular arthritis (knee/ankle)
    • Erysipelas-like rash
    • Proteinuria from AA amyloidosis
  • Complications:
    • AA amyloidosis → nephrotic syndrome
  • Treatment:
    • Colchicine (first-line, prevents attacks and amyloidosis)
    • Anti-IL-1β (canakinumab) in resistant cases

Explanation of other options:

Ankylosing spondylitis (Option A): Chronic inflammatory back pain; no episodic fevers/serositis.

Reactive arthritis (Option B): Post-infectious triad (arthritis, conjunctivitis, urethritis); not periodic fever.

Tuberculosis (Option D): Chronic infection, not short relapsing attacks; no ethnic clustering.

Rash seen in familial Mediterranean fever

questions.text: A 20-year-old male with a history of recurrent fevers since childhood comes to you. In addition to fever, he has repeated attacks of migratory myalgia with conjunctival congestion. Which inherited fever syndromes will you suspect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

TRAPS (TNF Receptor Associated Periodic Syndrome):

  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant.
  • Key features:
    • Migratory myalgia: Pain moves from one muscle group to another.
    • Ocular involvement: Conjunctival congestion or periorbital edema.
    • Recurrent fever episodes lasting >1 week.
    • Abdominal pain, skin rash, and serositis may occur.
  • Treatment:
    • Corticosteroids help during acute attacks.
    • Etanercept (soluble TNF receptor) can be used for prevention.
    • Anti-TNF monoclonal antibodies (like infliximab) are avoided as they may worsen the disease.

Explanation of other options:

Familial Mediterranean Fever (FMF) (Option A): FMF is an autosomal recessive autoinflammatory disease, classically seen in people of Armenian, Arab, and Sephardic Jewish ancestry. It presents with recurrent short (1-3 day) episodes of fever, abdominal or chest pain from serositis, and an erysipelas-like rash over the legs. It does not cause conjunctival congestion or migratory myalgia.

Mevalonate Kinase Deficiency (Hyper-IgD Syndrome) (Option C): This is an autosomal recessive condition due to mutations in the mevalonate kinase enzyme. It causes recurrent fever episodes associated with painful cervical lymphadenopathy, oral ulcers, and a maculopapular rash, often triggered by vaccinations or stress. Conjunctival congestion and migratory muscle pains are not typical features.

Muckle-Wells Syndrome (Cryopyrinopathy) (Option D):
Muckle-Wells is an autosomal dominant disorder under cryopyrin-associated periodic syndromes (CAPS). It manifests with recurrent fever, urticarial rash, arthritis, and conjunctivitis, with progressive sensorineural hearing loss and risk of AA amyloidosis. Migratory myalgia and prolonged febrile episodes are less prominent compared to TRAPS.

questions.text: Which of the following autoinflammatory syndromes shows clock-like regularity of episodes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

PFAPA (Periodic Fever, Aphthous Stomatitis, Pharyngitis, Adenitis):

  • It is the most common autoinflammatory syndrome in children.
  • Characterized by clock-like periodicity of episodes every 3-6 weeks.
  • Episodes include high fever, aphthous ulcers, pharyngitis, and cervical adenitis with normal growth and well-being between episodes.
  • Attacks typically resolve spontaneously within a few days.

Explanation of other options:

FMF (Familial Mediterranean Fever) (Option A): AR disorder common in Armenians, Arabs, and Sephardic Jews. Presents with short (24-72 hr) fever attacks, serositis, arthritis, and erysipelas-like rash. Episodes are not clock-like; they are triggered by stress or exertion and vary in frequency.

Muckle Wells Syndrome (Option C): An autosomal dominant cryopyrinopathy characterized by recurrent fevers, urticaria-like rash, conjunctivitis, hearing loss, and risk of amyloidosis. Attacks are irregular and may be triggered by cold or stress, not periodic like PFAPA.

Mevalonate Kinase Deficiency (Hyper-IgD Syndrome) (Option D): AR disorder with recurrent fever, lymphadenopathy, and rash, often triggered by vaccines or infections. Fever episodes do not follow a fixed schedule and are variable.

questions.text: Which of the following autoinflammatory diseases is not due to mutations involving the IL-1 pathway?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Blau's Syndrome
    • Caused by NOD2 gene mutations, leading to a granulomatous autoinflammatory disease.
    • Characterized by the triad of granulomatous dermatitis, arthritis, and uveitis.
    • Does not involve the IL-1 pathway, unlike most other autoinflammatory syndromes.
  • Other autoinflammatory conditions, such as FMF (Familial Mediterranean Fever), Muckle-Wells Syndrome (Cryopyrinopathies), and PFAPA, are mediated by overactivation of the IL-1 pathway.
  • Additional autoinflammatory syndromes not involving IL-1:
    • Blau syndrome (NOD2 mutations, granuloma formation)
    • DADA2 (Deficiency of Adenosine Deaminase 2)
    • Pyogenic arthritis, pyoderma gangrenosum, and acne syndrome (PAPA - PSTPIP1 mutations)

Explanation of other options:

FMF (Familial Mediterranean Fever) (Option B): Due to pyrin (MEFV gene) dysfunction causing overactivation of the inflammasome → IL-1β excess.

PFAPA (Option C): Periodic Fever, Aphthous Stomatitis, Pharyngitis, Adenitis syndrome. Pathogenesis involves innate immune activation with IL-1 dysregulation, although no single gene defect has been identified.

Muckle-Wells syndrome (Option D): Part of cryopyrinopathies (CAPS) due to NLRP3 gene mutations. Overactivation of NLRP3 inflammasome → excessive IL-1β release.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old patient has a set of investigations due to lethargy. She complains of polyuria and generalised back pains. Upon investigation, she has the following results:
Hb: 8 g/dl
MCV: 100 fl
Platelets: 190 x 10^9/L total protein 9 g/dl
Albumin: 3.4 (3.7-4.9) g/dl
calcium: 12 mg/dl
phosphate: 1.8 mg/dl
What is the appropriate next investigation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient's presentation strongly suggests multiple myeloma:

Key findings from the case:

  • Bone pain (back pain) → lytic bone lesions
  • Hypercalcemia (12 mg/dl) → due to bone destruction
  • Normo- to macrocytic anemia (Hb 8 g/dl, MCV 100)
  • Raised total protein with low albumin → reversal of albumin: globulin ratio due to monoclonal protein
  • Polyuria → from hypercalcemia
  • A normal platelet count rules out pancytopenia from other causes

Next best step:

  • Serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP) detects M-protein/monoclonal (paraprotein) band.
  • If positive, this is followed by immunofixation and serum-free light chains.
  • Bone marrow biopsy is confirmatory but done after SPEP.

Explanation of other potions:

Complete liver function tests (Option A): LFT abnormalities do not explain hypercalcemia, high protein with low albumin, and bone pain.

Urinary albumin or 24-hour urine protein (Option B): These may detect Bence-Jones proteins (light chains), but SPEP is more diagnostic as an initial step.

24-hour urine protein (Option D): Used later in the workup, after SPEP suggests myeloma.

questions.text: A 33-year-old retired athlete presents with severe burning pain affecting the right leg and foot. 4 months earlier, he had several arthroscopic washouts for septic arthritis affecting his right knee, which followed an injury. Examination reveals a reduced range of movement of the right knee and ankle. There was diffuse swelling of the right leg and foot with overlying cool, scaly skin. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This presentation is classic for Reflex Sympathetic Dystrophy (RSD), now called Complex Regional Pain Syndrome type I (CRPS I). 

Key Points Supporting CRPS:

  1. History of trauma/surgery
    • CRPS often occurs after injury, immobilization, or surgery (in this case, septic arthritis and multiple washouts).
  2. Symptoms
    • Severe burning pain disproportionate to the initial insult
    • Swelling and trophic changes: cool, scaly skin
    • Joint stiffness and reduced range of motion
  3. Four diagnostic features of CRPS:
    • Sensory: Allodynia and hyperalgesia (burning pain)
    • Vasomotor: Temperature or color asymmetry (cool limb)
    • Sudomotor: Edema or sweating changes
    • Trophic: Skin, hair, or nail changes (atrophy, shiny or scaly skin)
  4. CRPS II (causalgia): occurs when there is a definite peripheral nerve injury, whereas CRPS I (RSD) occurs without a clear nerve lesion.

Examination of other options:

Compartment syndrome (Option A): Acute, very painful, tense compartments; occurs immediately after injury. Chronic swelling months later is not consistent.

Deep vein thrombosis (Option B): DVT presents with warm, red, swollen limb and does not explain burning pain and skin/trophic changes.

Raynaud's phenomenon (Option D): Raynaud's affects fingers/toes with color changes (white-blue-red) triggered by cold or stress, not chronic swelling and pain after surgery.

Reflex sympathetic dystrophy affecting the right foot

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of the femoral head

questions.text:
A 54-year-old female has been on long-term steroids for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. She complains of pain in her right groin radiating down the anteromedial thigh. She has an antalgic gait. On examination of the hip, there is decreased range of movement, especially flexion, abduction, and internal rotation.
What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is Avascular Necrosis (AVN) of the femoral head, most commonly caused by long-term corticosteroid use or alcohol abuse.

Key supporting points:

  1. Risk factor:
    • Long-term steroid therapy is a classic cause of AVN (disruption of blood supply to the femoral head).
  2. Symptoms:
    • Deep groin pain radiating to the thigh (anteromedial)
    • Pain worsens with weight bearing, causing an antalgic gait.
  3. Signs:
    • Loss of hip movements, particularly internal rotation, abduction, and flexion, is the earliest sign in AVN.
  4. Investigations:
    • MRI is the most sensitive for early detection (before X-ray changes).
    • X-rays may be normal early on, but later show crescent sign and collapse of the head.

Explanation of other options:

Osteoarthritis (Option A): More common in older age; presents with gradual stiffness, crepitus, and radiographic joint space narrowing. AVN has a specific risk factor (steroids) and can be more acute.

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option B): Usually bilateral, with systemic symptoms and other joint involvement. No mention of inflammatory polyarthritis here.

Metastatic hip lesion (Option C): Would typically cause night pain and bony tenderness. Imaging (X-ray) would likely reveal lytic/blastic lesions rather than movement-specific pain.

questions.text: A 31-year-old upper-middle-class white lady who used to be an athlete has been referred for investigation due to tiredness. She mentions fatigue, which is chronic and occurs even after minor physical work. This has been going on for 3 years. Investigations, including CK, ESR, EMGs, and muscle biopsy, have revealed no obvious medical cause for this. Which of the following is the best treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation: 

This presentation is typical of Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS), also called Myalgic Encephalomyelitis (ME):

Key clues in this case:

  • Chronic duration (>6 months)
  • Fatigue after minor exertion (post-exertional malaise)
  • Normal muscle and inflammatory investigations
  • No evidence of a primary muscle, joint, or inflammatory disorder

Clinical features of CFS/ME:

  • Persistent fatigue with:
    • Post-exertional malaise (symptoms worsen after minimal effort)
    • Unrefreshing sleep
    • Cognitive impairment ("brain fog")
    • Orthostatic intolerance
  • Other possible symptoms:
    • Myalgia, arthralgia
    • Sore throat, tender lymph nodes
    • Sensory hypersensitivity, difficulty in temperature regulation

Treatment:

  • Graded exercise therapy (GET):
    • Gradual, structured physical activity to prevent deconditioning.
    • Patients must be educated about pacing to avoid worsening symptoms.
  • Additional supportive measures:
    • Sleep hygiene (sometimes melatonin or low-dose amitriptyline)
    • Pain clinic referral if pain is significant
    • CBT may be an adjunct but is not the first-line treatment.

Explanation of other options:

Erythropoietin (Option A): Used for anemia, not indicated here.

Cognitive behavioural therapy (Option B): Can help with coping strategies but is not the primary management.

Codeine (Option D): Analgesics do not address the underlying fatigue and risk of dependence.

questions.text: A 21-year-old lady has a swinging fever, significant weight loss over 2 months, generalised myalgia, polyarthralgia affecting wrists, knees, ankles, elbows, metacarpophalangeal joints, and a sore throat. Investigations show: Hb 9.5g/l, MCV 85 fl, ESR 92 mm in first hour, CRP 45 g/l, serum ferritin 1600 mg/dl, RF negative, ANA negative, ENA negative, ASO titre <200iu. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This presentation is classic for Adult-onset Still's Disease (AOSD):

Key Features Supporting AOSD:

  1. Systemic symptoms:
    • Prolonged high-grade swinging fever
    • Weight loss, myalgia, and pharyngitis (sore throat)
  2. Articular involvement:
    • Polyarthralgia/polyarthritis predominantly affecting wrists, knees, ankles, and MCP joints
  3. Laboratory profile:
    • Very high serum ferritin (often >1000 ng/mL) is strongly suggestive.
    • Markedly raised ESR/CRP
    • Negative RF, ANA, ENA (seronegative inflammatory syndrome)
  4. Typical rash (often seen but may be transient):
    • Evanescent, salmon-colored macular or maculopapular rash (can be missed)

Important Points about AOSD:

  • Etiology: Unknown; systemic inflammatory disease.
  • Triad: Fever + rash + arthritis (may not be present together early).
  • Course:
    • 1/3 monophasic (resolves)
    • 1/3 polycyclic (recurrent episodes)
    • 1/3 chronic progressive arthritis
  • Complications: Macrophage activation syndrome (MAS), severe joint damage.

Examination of other options:

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option A): Usually RF/anti-CCP positive, chronic symmetrical small joint involvement; ferritin is not typically very high.

Ankylosing spondylitis (Option B): Presents with axial spine symptoms (low back pain), sacroiliitis, HLA-B27 association, and not a high swinging fever or sore throat.

Inclusion body myositis (Option D): Causes muscle weakness (especially distal and quadriceps) with normal/increased CK; no fever with sore throat and very high ferritin.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with an acute onset of severe pain and swelling of the left elbow. He mentions that he had a chest infection 3 weeks ago. On examination, he had a temperature of 38°C and the left elbow was erythematous, swollen and tender. What is the most appropriate investigation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient has acute monoarthritis with fever, swelling, erythema, and tenderness of a single joint following a recent infection - this strongly suggests septic arthritis, although gout and crystal arthropathies are also possible.
  • Joint aspiration is the single most important and first-line investigation for any acute monoarthritis, as it:
    • Confirms the diagnosis by analyzing synovial fluid (Gram stain, culture, and crystal examination).
    • Helps distinguish between septic arthritis (purulent fluid, organisms present) and crystal-induced arthritis (urate or CPPD crystals).
  • Delay in aspirating a joint risks joint destruction in septic arthritis.

Explanation of other options:

C-reactive protein (CRP) (Option A): CRP is nonspecific and will be elevated in both septic and crystal arthritis. It cannot confirm the diagnosis.

Full blood count (Option B): May show leukocytosis, but this is also nonspecific and does not guide definitive management.

Uric acid level (Option D): Uric acid can be normal during an acute gout flare and may also be elevated in people without gout, so it is not reliable in acute monoarthritis.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man presents with a painful, swollen left knee as well as pain and stiffness in both his hands. On examination, his skin is pigmented. There is tenderness and swelling of the 2nd and 3rd metacarpophalangeal joints of both hands, and he has hepatomegaly of 8 cm below the costal margin. His knee is swollen, and aspiration of the joint yields turbid, straw coloured fluid. Which one of the following diagnoses is likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

This presentation is classic for haemochromatosis arthropathy:

  • Key clues:
    • Skin pigmentation ("bronze diabetes")
    • Hepatomegaly (iron deposition in the liver)
    • Arthropathy of 2nd and 3rd metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints - this is very characteristic of haemochromatosis.
    • Knee effusion with straw-coloured synovial fluid - CPPD (pseudogout) due to chondrocalcinosis is common in haemochromatosis.
  • Mechanism:
    Excess iron deposition damages cartilage → chondrocalcinosis → CPPD crystal deposition → chronic arthropathy and recurrent pseudo-gout attacks.

Explanation of other options:

Wilson's disease (Option A): Presents with hepatic, neuropsychiatric symptoms, and Kayser-Fleischer rings. Arthropathy may occur, but pigmentation and classic 2nd/3rd MCP involvement are not typical.

Pseudohypoparathyroidism (Option C): Causes Albright's hereditary osteodystrophy (short 4th/5th metacarpals, round facies) but not bronze skin or hepatomegaly.

Pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism (Option D): Has similar skeletal features as pseudohypoparathyroidism but normal biochemistry; no liver or skin findings.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old man presents with a hot, swollen elbow joint. He has a temperature of 37

°C and CRP of 350 mg/l. A diagnosis of septic arthritis is suspected. Which of the following organisms is most commonly isolated from joints?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Staphylococcus aureus

  • The most common cause of septic arthritis in adults (>50% of cases).
  • Risk factors: pre-existing joint disease, prosthetic joints, skin infections, immunosuppression, IVDU.
  • Pathogenesis: hematogenous spread leading to rapid joint destruction if untreated.

Explanation of other options:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae (Option B): A common cause in young, sexually active adults, but overall less frequent than Staph aureus. Often causes migratory polyarthritis, tenosynovitis, and skin pustules.

β-haemolytic streptococcus (Option C): Can cause septic arthritis, but is less common; more often seen in neonates and occasionally in adults with preceding pharyngitis.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Option D): Rare cause; associated with immunocompromised hosts and IV drug users (often involving sternoclavicular joints).

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy has a fever. He has had elbow, shoulder, hip, and knee pains over the last few months. On examination, he has a temperature of 37.5°C and palpable hepatosplenomegaly. Investigations show a CRP of 30 and negative ANA. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This presentation is classic for Systemic-onset Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA):

Key features of systemic-onset JIA

  • Age <16 years
  • Prolonged arthritis (multiple joints)
  • Systemic features:
    • Daily or intermittent fever
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Generalized lymphadenopathy
    • Evanescent, salmon-pink macular rash
    • Possible serositis (pleuritis, pericarditis)
  • Laboratory findings:
    • ANA and rheumatoid factor: negative
    • Elevated ESR/CRP, anemia, and possible transaminase elevation
    • Ferritin may be very high (especially in macrophage activation syndrome).

Important complication:

  • Macrophage Activation Syndrome (MAS) - life-threatening, needs to be recognized early.

Explanation of other options:

Marfan's syndrome (Option A): Connective tissue disorder with tall stature, lens dislocation, aortic root dilation-not inflammatory arthritis.

Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (Option B): Features hyperextensible skin, hypermobile joints, easy bruising; no fever or organomegaly.

Perthes disease (Option C): Avascular necrosis of the femoral head in young boys; localized hip pain/limp, not polyarthritis or systemic features.

questions.text: A 24-year-old lady presents to the clinic with a painfully swollen, hot right knee. She gives a 2-week history of migratory polyarthritis and urethritis. Clinical examination reveals a pustular skin rash, right Achilles tendinitis, and left plantar fasciitis. She is HLA-B27 negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI), which classically presents in two stages:

  1. Bacteremic phase: Fever, migratory polyarthritis, tenosynovitis, and pustular skin rash.
  2. Localized septic arthritis phase: Monoarthritis, often of the knee.

The key distinguishing feature here is the migratory nature of arthritis (one joint improves as another becomes inflamed), along with pustular skin lesions.

HLA-B27 negativity also makes reactive arthritis less likely in this patient.

Explanation of other options:

Reiter's Syndrome (Reactive Arthritis) (Option A): Triad- Urethritis, arthritis, conjunctivitis/uveitis. The arthritis pattern is additive, not migratory, and the skin lesions are keratoderma blennorrhagicum (not pustular). Strongly associated with HLA-B27 positivity.

Relapsing Polychondritis (Option B): Multisystem autoimmune disease affecting cartilage (ears, nose, trachea). Joint pain can occur, but skin pustules and urethritis are not typical.

Non-specific Urethritis (Option D): Caused by organisms like Chlamydia, Mycoplasma. No systemic migratory arthritis or pustular rash.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is investigated for swelling and pain in the right wrist, left knee, and right ankle. Investigations show a positive ANA 1:160 with -ve Rheumatoid factor. What is she at risk of developing?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This presentation is most consistent with Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA), particularly the oligoarticular subtype:
    • Arthritis lasting > 6 weeks in children under 16.
    • ANA positive and Rheumatoid factor negative strongly suggests oligoarticular JIA.
  • Complication:
    • These children are at high risk of developing chronic anterior uveitis (iridocyclitis), often asymptomatic initially and requiring regular slit-lamp screening.

Explanation of other options:

Psoriasis (Option A): Would suggest psoriatic JIA, but this case does not describe psoriatic lesions or a family history of psoriasis.

Butterfly facial rash (Option B): Suggestive of SLE, but here ANA positivity is isolated, and SLE would also have other features (malar rash, hematologic, renal).

Erosive joint disease (Option C): More typical of polyarticular RF-positive JIA or adult rheumatoid arthritis, not oligoarticular JIA.

Uveitis causing red eye (lenticular precipitates may be seen)
